abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p:
We propose a method of detecting the dark matter axion by using two slabs of a conductor. The flat surfaces are set face to face, parallel to each other. An external magnetic field B parallel to the surfaces is applied. Radiation converted from the axion arises between the two slabs. When we tune the spacing l between the two surfaces such that l = π/m a with axion mass m a , a resonance occurs so that the radiation becomes strong. Furthermore, the electric current flowing on the surface of the slabs is enhanced. We show that the electric current is large enough to be detectable at the resonance. It reaches 0.7 × 10 −9 A $(10^{-5}\, \mbox{eV}/m_a)^{1/2} \, (B/5\, \mbox{T}) \, (L/10\, \mbox{cm}) \, (\sigma /3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV)$
using 6N copper for the square slabs with side length L and high electrical conductivity σ at temperature T ∼ 1 K. The power of the Joule heating is $0.3\times 10^{-22} \, \mbox{W} \, (B/5 \, \mbox{T})^2 \, (10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a)^{1/2} \, (L/10 \, \mbox{cm})^2 \, (\sigma /3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV)$ . When we amplify the power using an LC circuit with factor Q LC, the signal-to-noise ratio is $4.5\times 10^{4} \, (Q_\mathrm{LC}/10^6) \, (B/5 \, \mbox{T})^2 \, (t_\mathrm{obs}/1\, \mathrm{s})^{1/2}\, (10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a) \, (L/10 \, \mbox{cm})^2 \, (\sigma /3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV)$
with an observation time of tobs.

body.p: The axion [1–6] is one of the most important candidates for dark matter. In particular, it appears that it stands above other candidates because the quantum chromodynamics (QCD) axion gives natural solutions for the strong charge–parity (CP) problem as well as the dark matter problem. Other dark matter candidates, e.g. WIMPs (weakly interacting massive particles) have not been detected in spite of extensive and protracted searches.

The axion has recently been sought in various ways. Most of the experiments [7–15] exploit the Primakoff effect. That is, they detect photons directly produced by the dark matter axion a(t) under a strong magnetic field B. But, the axion–photon coupling ga γγa(t) ∼ 10−19 is so tiny that direct photon production is hard to detect. So, we need, for instance, a very sensitive radio receiver using technology such as superconducting quantum interference devices.

In this letter we propose a new detection method for the dark matter axion, performed by observing the electric current flowing in a conductor with high electrical conductivity. The current is induced by the axion under a strong magnetic field $\vec{B}$ . We use two parallel slabs [16], see Fig. 1, which are set face to face. When we apply a magnetic field between the slabs, the axion is converted to radiation between the slabs. Simultaneously, an electric current I a flows in the surfces of the slabs in the direction parallel to the magnetic field $\vec{B}$ . When we appropriately tune the spacing l between the parallel slabs, a resonance occurs and the radiation is enhanced. At the resonance, the electric current is also enhanced. We find that the electric current reaches ∼10−10 A $(10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a)^{1/2} \, (B/5 \, \mbox{T})(L/10 \, \mbox{cm})^2 \, (\sigma /3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV)$
using high-quality 6N copper for the square slabs with side length L = 10 cm and high electrical conductivity σ ≃ 3.3 × 10 7 eV at T = 1 K. This system resembles the system used in the Axion Dark Matter Experiment, where a cylindrical conductor is used to obtain the resonance. In addition to amplification of the radiation by tuning the spacing, we also amplify the electric current with an LC circuit [17,18] by tuning the circuit parameters. Consequently, we can obtain sufficient power, ${\sim } 10^{-17} \, \mbox{W} \, (Q_\mathrm{LC}/10^6) \, (10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a)^{1/2} \, (B/5 \, \mbox{T})^2 \, (L/10 \, \mbox{cm})^2 \, (\sigma /3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV)$ , to be detected by a circuit with factor QLC.

caption.p: Rectangular flat conductors of size L × R and spacing l. An electric current I a flows on the surface.

body.p:
Before we discuss the radiation in the space between the two slabs of normal conductors, we briefly explain the axion–photon coupling. The axion $a(\vec{x},t)$
couples with both electric $\vec{E}$ and magnetic fields $\vec{B}$ in the following way, (1) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} L_{aEB}= g_{\gamma }\alpha \frac{a(\vec{x},t)\vec{E}\cdot \vec{B}}{f_a\pi }\equiv g_{a\gamma \gamma } a(\vec{x},t)\vec{E}\cdot \vec{B} , \end{eqnarray*} $$ with the decay constant f a of the axion and the fine structure constant α ≃ 1/137, where the numerical constant gγ depends on the axion model; typically it is of the order of one. The standard notation gaγγ is such that $g_{a\gamma \gamma }=g_{\gamma }\alpha /f_a\pi \simeq 0.14 \, (m_a/\rm GeV^2)$ for the Dine–Fischler–Srednicki–Zhitnitsky (DFSZ) model [19,20] and $g_{a\gamma \gamma }\simeq -0.39 \, (m_a/\rm GeV^2)$ for the Kim–Shifman–Vainshtein–Zakharov (KSVZ) model [21,22]. In other words, gγ ≃ 0.37 for DFSZ and gγ ≃ −0.96 for KSVZ. The axion decay constant f a is related to the axion mass m a in the QCD axion: $m_af_a\simeq 6\times 10^{-6} \, \rm eV\times 10^{12}$ GeV. We only consider the QCD axion in this paper.

Because the de Broglie wavelength of the axion inside our galaxy is 103 times larger than $m_a^{-1}$ , we may neglect the spatial dependence of the axion field in experiments: $a(\vec{x},t)=a(t)$ . We can see that the coupling parameter ga γγa(t) in the Lagrangian, Eq. (1), is extremely small for the dark matter axion a(t). We note that the energy density of the dark matter axion taken by time average is given by (2) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \rho _a= \frac{1}{2}\overline{\left(\dot{a}^2+(\vec{\partial } a)^2+m_a^2a^2\right)}\simeq \frac{m_a^2a_0^2}{2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where $a(t)=a_0\cos \big (t\sqrt{m_a^2+k^2} \big )\simeq a_0\cos (m_a t)$ , because the velocity k/m a of the axion is about 10−3 in our galaxy.

The local energy density ρ of dark matter in our galaxy is $\rho \simeq 0.3 \, \rm GeV\, \rm cm^{-3}\simeq 2.4\times 10^{-42} \, \rm GeV^4$ . Assuming that the density is equal to that of the dark matter axion, i.e. ρ = ρ a , we find an extremely small parameter g aγγa ∼ 10−19. The energy density also gives a large number density for the axions of $\rho _a/m_a\sim 10^{15} \, \mbox{cm}^{-3} \, (10^{-6} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a)$ , which gives rise to their coherence. This allows us to treat the axions as the classical axion field a(t)∝cos (m a t), smoothly varying spatially. The parameter gaγγa (t) is extremely small, so perturbative analysis is valid.

The interaction term in Eq. (1) between the axion and the electromagnetic field slightly modifies the Maxwell equations in the vacuum between the two slabs, (3) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rllc}\vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{E}+g_{a\gamma \gamma }\vec{\partial }\cdot (a(t)\vec{B}) & = 0, & \quad \vec{\partial }\times \big (\vec{B}-g_{a\gamma \gamma }a(t)\vec{E}\big )- \partial _t\big (\vec{E}+g_{a\gamma \gamma }a(t)\vec{B}\big ) & = 0, \\ \vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{B} & = 0, & \quad \vec{\partial }\times \vec{E}+\partial _t \vec{B} & = 0.\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ From the equations, we obtain approximately the electric field $\vec{E}$
generated by the axion a(t) under a static and spatially homogeneous background magnetic field $\vec{B}$ . It is assumed to be of the order of ga γγa(t)B, (4) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \vec{E}_a(t)=-g_{a\gamma \gamma }a(t)\vec{B}. \end{eqnarray*} $$ Other solutions are those of standard electromagnetic waves in vacuum.

Now, we discuss [16] the radiation arising between the two slabs, and the electric currents flowing in the slabs. In order to discuss the electric and magnetic fields in slabs composed of a normal conductor, we suppose the conductor to have trivial permeability μ = 1, dielectric permittivity ϵ = 1, and large electrical conductivity σ.

The configuration of the conductors, shown in Fig. 1, are as follows. Conductors with flat surfaces are placed parallel to each other. They occupy the regions x ≥ 0 and x ≤ −l. Their surfaces are at x = 0 and x = −l, respectively. They are uniform in the y and z directions. We impose a spatially uniform static magnetic field $\vec{B}=(0,0,B)$
parallel to the surfaces of the conductors. We denote the magnetic field induced in the conductor as $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})+\vec{B}$ . The term $\vec{B}$
corresponds to the external magnetic field $\vec{B}$
because the component of the field $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})+\vec{B}$
parallel to the surface (at x = 0 and x = −l) must be continuous at the surface. Although we assume the two slabs extend indefinitely in the y and z directions, the results obtained below are valid as long as the wavelength of the radiation is much smaller than the actual length of the conductors.

The electromagnetic fields in the conductor are described by the modified Maxwell equations, (5) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} &&\vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})+g_{a\gamma \gamma }\vec{\partial }\cdot \big (a(t)\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})\big )=0, \\ &&\vec{\partial }\times \big (\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})-g_{a\gamma \gamma } a(t)\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})\big )- \partial _t\big (\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})+g_{a\gamma \gamma } a(t)\big (\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})+\vec{B}\big )\big )=\vec{J}_e, \\ &&\vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{B}(\mbox{inside})=0, \qquad \vec{\partial }\times \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})+\partial _t \vec{B}(\mbox{inside})=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$ where we denote the electric field induced in the conductors as $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ .

In Eq. (5) we have included the current $\vec{J}_e=\sigma \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$
induced by the electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ , but have neglected the external current $\vec{J}_\mathrm{ext}$
generating the background static magnetic field $\vec{B}$ ( $\vec{\partial }\times \vec{B}=\vec{J}_\mathrm{ext}$ ). This current is outside the system. Here we have assumed Ohm’s law, $\vec{J}_e=\sigma \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ . Only the presence of the current $\vec{J}_e$
distinguishes the Maxwell equations in the conductor from those in the vacuum.

When we neglect the axion contribution, we obtain the magnetic field $\vec{B}$
inside the conductor. Obviously, there is no electric field inside the conductor. Once we take into account the axion contribution, the oscillating electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ is induced as well as the magnetic field $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})$ in addition to $\vec{B}$ .

Assuming that the parameter gaγγ a(t) is small, and noting that the fields $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ and $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})$ are of the order of gaγγa (t), we derive the equations (6) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rl}\vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{E}(\mbox{inside}) = 0, & \qquad \vec{\partial }\times \vec{B}(\mbox{inside}) = \vec{J}_e+\partial _t(\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})-\vec{E}_a), \\ \vec{\partial }\cdot \vec{B}(\mbox{inside}) = 0, & \qquad \vec{\partial }\times \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})+\partial _t \vec{B}(\mbox{inside}) = 0,\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ where we have used the relation $\vec{\partial }\times \vec{E}_a=0$
because $\vec{\partial }\times \vec{B}=0$
inside the conductor.

Using Ohm’s law, $\vec{J}_e=\sigma \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ , in Eq. (6), we derive the equation for $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ , (7) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \left(\vec{\partial }^2-\partial _t^2\right)\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})=\sigma \partial _t\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})-\partial _t^2\vec{E}_a , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where we note that $\vec{E}_a\propto \cos (m_at)$ . Then, we find a solution for x > 0 (later, we discuss the solution for x < −l), (8) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})\simeq \vec{E}_1\exp \bigg (-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\cos \bigg (\omega t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )+A\sin \bigg (\omega t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ) +\frac{1}{\sigma }\partial _t \vec{E}_a, \end{eqnarray*} $$ with arbitrary field strength $\vec{E}_1$ , parameter A, and frequency ω. The skin depth δ e is given by $\delta _e=\sqrt{2/\sigma \omega }$ . In the derivation, we have neglected the term $\partial _t^2\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ on the left-hand side of Eq. (7), which is much smaller than the term $\sigma \partial _t\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ on the right-hand side. Namely, we have used the inequality σ ≫ ω ( ∼ m a ) because the electric conductivity σ ∼ 104 eV of copper is much larger than the axion mass m a = 10−6 eV ∼10−3 eV under consideration. We note that the parameter $m_a\delta _e=\sqrt{2m_a/\sigma }$ is very small, such as m a δ e ∼ 10−4 for $m_a\sim 10^{-5} \, \rm eV$ and σ ∼ 103 eV.

The first term of the solution represents radiation not propagating in the z and y directions. It is only present in the surface of the conductor due to the skin effect. It induces an electric current $\sigma \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$ on the surface. Although ω is arbitrary at this stage, it turns out from the boundary conditions at x = 0, −l that it is equal to m a . Hence, we put ω = m a hereafter. Furthermore, the boundary conditions make the electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$
parallel to $\vec{B}$ : $\vec{E}_1=(0,0,E_1)$ , just as $\vec{E}_a=-g_{a\gamma \gamma }a(t)\vec{B}$ .

The second term represents the oscillating electric field $\frac{1}{\sigma }\partial _t \vec{E}_a$
present uniformly inside the conductor. This term is absent when we consider a conductor with finite length in the z direction because the electric charges on the two ends of the upper and lower surfaces induced by the electric field screen the field $\frac{1}{\sigma }\partial _t \vec{E}_a$ . Hereafter, we neglect the term $\frac{1}{\sigma }\partial _t \vec{E}_a$ .

We also have the magnetic field $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})=(0,B_y(\mbox{inside}),0)$ , corresponding to the electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})=(0,0,E_z(\mbox{inside}))$ , because $\vec{\partial }\times \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})=-\partial _t \vec{B}(\mbox{inside})$ , (9) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} B_y(\mbox{inside}) & =& -\frac{E_1}{\delta _e m_a}\exp \bigg (-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\sin \bigg (m_a t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg ) + \cos \bigg (m_a t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ) \\ &&-\; \frac{AE_1}{\delta _e m_a}\exp \bigg (-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\sin \bigg (m_a t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg ) -\cos \bigg (m_a t-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ). \end{eqnarray*} $$ As a whole, we find the magnetic field $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})+\vec{B}$ as well as the electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})$
inside the conductor (x > 0).

The strength $\vec{E}_1$
(frequency ω and parameter A) is determined by the boundary conditions at the surfaces x = 0 and x = −l. The boundary conditions we impose demand that the parallel components of the electric and magnetic fields on both sides of the boundary must be continuous. That is, $\vec{E}(\mbox{inside})=\vec{E}_a+\vec{E}(\mbox{outside})$ and $\vec{B}(\mbox{inside})=\vec{B}(\mbox{outside})$ , where the fields $\vec{E}(\mbox{outside})$ and $\vec{B}(\mbox{outside})$
represent standing waves arising in the space between the two slabs. This implies that we only consider the mode of the electric field $\vec{E}(\mbox{outside})=(0,0,E_z(\mbox{outside}))$ and magnetic field $\vec{B}(\mbox{outside})=(0,B_y(\mbox{outside}),0)$
arising between the two slabs. They represent the lowest transverse mode not propagating in the z and y directions. They depend only on the coordinate x and t. Then, the solutions of the Maxwell equations in a vacuum representing the mode are (10) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_z(\mbox{outside}) &=& -b_1\cos (m_ax+\delta _1)\cos (m_at)+b_2\cos (m_ax+\delta _2)\sin (m_at) , \\ B_y(\mbox{outside}) &=& b_1\sin (m_ax+\delta _1)\sin (m_at)+b_2\sin (m_ax+\delta _2)\cos (m_at) , \end{eqnarray*} $$ with constants b1, 2 and δ1, 2. Additionally, we have the electric field $\vec{E}_a=-g_{a\gamma \gamma }a(t)\vec{B}= \big (0,0,-g_{a\gamma \gamma }a_0\cos (m_at) B\big )\equiv \big (0,0,E_a\cos (m_at)\big )$
induced by the axion between the slabs, E a ≡ −g aγγa0B.

We determine the constants E1, A, b1, 2, and δ1, 2 by imposing the boundary conditions E z (inside) = E z (outside) + E a , B y (inside) = B y (outside) at x = 0: (11) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rlrl}b_1\sin \delta _1 & = -\frac{E_1(1+A)}{m_a\delta _e}, &\qquad b_2\sin \delta _2 & = -\frac{E_1(1-A)}{m_a\delta _e} , \\ E_a-b_1\cos \delta _1 & = E_1, & \qquad b_2\cos \delta _2 & = A E_1.\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ Additionally, by imposing the boundary condition at x = −l, we obtain (12) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rlrl}b_1\sin (\delta _1-m_al) & = +\frac{E_1(1+A)}{m_a\delta _e} , &\quad b_2\sin (\delta _2-m_al) & = +\frac{E_1(1-A)}{m_a\delta _e} , \\ E_a-b_1\cos (\delta _1-m_al) & = E_1 , & \quad b_2\cos (\delta _2-m_al) & = AE_1 .\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ In order to obtain the relations from the boundary condition at x = −l, we note that the solutions of the electric and magnetic fields inside the conductor, x ≤ −l, are given by (13) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_z(\mbox{inside},l) & =& +E_1\exp \bigg (\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\cos \bigg (\omega t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )+A\sin \bigg (\omega t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ) , \\ B_y(\mbox{inside},l) & =& +\frac{E_1}{\delta _e m_a}\exp \bigg (\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\sin \bigg (m_a t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg ) +\cos \bigg (m_a t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ) \\ &&+\; \frac{AE_1}{\delta _e m_a}\exp \bigg (\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg (\sin \bigg (m_a t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg ) -\cos \bigg (m_a t+\frac{x+l}{\delta _e}\bigg )\bigg ) . \end{eqnarray*} $$

Therefore, we find that the coefficients E1 and AE 1, as well as b1, 2, are such that (14) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rlrl}E_1 & = E_a \displaystyle\frac{(m_a\delta _e\tan \delta )^2-m_a\delta _e\tan \delta }{1+(m_a\delta _e\tan \delta -1)^2} , \qquad & E_1A & = -E_a \displaystyle\frac{m_a\delta _e\tan \delta }{1+(m_a\delta _e\tan \delta -1)^2} , \\[5pt] b_1 & = \displaystyle\frac{E_a}{\cos \delta }\, \displaystyle\frac{2-m_a\delta _e\tan \delta }{1+(m_a\delta _e\tan \delta -1)^2}, & \qquad b_2 & = - \displaystyle\frac{E_a}{\cos \delta }\, \displaystyle\frac{m_a\delta _e\tan \delta }{1+(m_a\delta _e\tan \delta -1)^2},\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ and the phases δ1, 2 = δ satisfying the identical equation (15) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \tan \delta =\frac{\sin (m_al)}{1+\cos (m_al)}. \end{eqnarray*} $$ Therefore, the coefficients behave in the limit of large electrical conductivity σ (small skin depth m a δ e ≪ 1) such that (16) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \begin{array}{rlrl}E_1 & = E_a\times O(m_a\delta _e), & \qquad A & = -1+O(m_a\delta _e), \\ b_1 & = \displaystyle\frac{E_a}{\cos \delta _1}\big (1+O(m_a\delta _e)\big ), &\qquad b_2 & = -\displaystyle\frac{E_a}{\cos \delta _1}O(m_a\delta _e).\end{array} \end{eqnarray*} $$ We find that the standing waves in Eq. (10) of the electromagnetic fields in the space between the two slabs are given, in the limit m a δ e → 0 ( $\delta _e=\sqrt{2/m_a\sigma }$ ) for σ → ∞, by (17) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_z(\mbox{outside}) &=& -\frac{E_a}{\cos \delta }\cos (m_ax+\delta )\cos (m_at) , \\ B_y(\mbox{outside}) &=& \frac{E_a}{\cos \delta }\sin (m_ax+\delta )\sin (m_at). \end{eqnarray*} $$

In addition to the standing waves, we have electric field E z (inside) in the conductor, (18) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \vec{E}(\mbox{inside})=(0,0,E_z), \qquad E_z=-\frac{E_am_a\delta _e\tan \delta }{\sqrt{2}}\exp \bigg (-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\sin \bigg (m_at-\frac{x}{\delta _e}+\frac{\pi }{4}\bigg ) , \end{eqnarray*} $$ which generates an electric current J = σE z (inside) in the surface of the conductor. These are solutions in the limit of a perfect conductor.

Because cos δ1 is of the order of 1, we find that the strengths of the standing waves in the space between the two slabs are identical to the electric field E a generated by the axion in vacuum. This is similar to the case in a resonant cavity, as pointed out in Ref. [16].

We note that in the limit of a perfect conductor with σ → ∞, the electric field E a + E z (outside) present between the slabs vanishes at the boundaries at x = 0 and x = − l. Similarly, we find that the electric field E(inside) ∼ E a × m a δ e inside the conductors vanishes in the perfect conductor limit. The magnetic field B y (inside) ∝ exp ( − x/δ e ) also vanishes. On the other hand, the magnetic field B y (outside) does not vanish at the boundaries, B y (outside) = E a tan δ sin (m a t) at x = 0 and x = −l. The discontinuity occurs because of the presence of the surface current. For instance, the surface current at x = 0 is given by (19) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} J_a=\sigma E(\mbox{inside}) \rightarrow -E_a\tan \delta \sin (m_at)\delta (x) \qquad \mbox{for } \sigma \rightarrow \infty . \end{eqnarray*} $$ This surface current generates the discontinuity ΔB ≡ B y (outside) − B y (inside) = E a tan δsin (m a t) at the surface.

We would like to make a comment on the results in our previous papers [23,24], in which electromagnetic radiation from a cylindrical conductor converted from the dark matter axion was discussed. There, we naively derived the electric current flowing at the surface induced by the axion without imposing appropriate boundary conditions; the boundary conditions are carefully treated here and in Ref. [16]. As a result, the radiation from the conductor was overestimated, as indicated in Ref. [16]. The electric fields did not vanish at the surface, even in the limit of a perfect conductor. Careful treatment [25] of the boundary conditions leads to a physically reasonable view: the radiation $\vec{E}_a$
arising in a vacuum from the axion under the magnetic field collides with the conductor and reflected radiation is just that emitted from the conductor. The reflected radiation is never enhanced compared with the incident radiation $\vec{E}_a$ . An identical conclusion was also reached in Ref. [ 18].

Now we show that a resonance occurs when we adjust the spacing l just as l = π/m a in the case of finite σ. (The results shown below hold even for l = π(2n + 1)/m a for a non-negative integer n.) The resonance implies that the electric and magnetic fields of radiation are enhanced compared with the radiation in Eq. (17). With the choice of l = π/m a we obtain δ = π/2, so that A = 0, E1 = E a , and $b_{1,2}=-\frac{E_a}{m_a\delta _e}$ . Therefore, the radiation fields E z (outside) and B y (outside) are enhanced with the enhancement factor 1/m a δ e , (20) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_z(\mbox{outside}) &=& \frac{\sqrt{2}E_a}{m_a\delta _e}\sin (m_ax)\sin \bigg (m_at-\frac{\pi }{4}\bigg ) , \\ B_y(\mbox{outside}) &=& -\frac{\sqrt{2}E_a}{m_a\delta _e}\cos (m_ax)\sin \bigg (m_at+\frac{\pi }{4}\bigg ). \end{eqnarray*} $$ We also have the electric field inside the conductor x > 0, (21) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_z(\mbox{inside})=E_a\exp \bigg ({-}\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\cos \bigg (m_at-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg ), \end{eqnarray*} $$ which induces a large oscillating electric current $\sigma E_a\exp \big ({-}\frac{x}{\delta _e}\big )\cos \big (m_at-\frac{x}{\delta _e}\big )$ in the surface.

We estimate the electric current $I_a(m_at)=L\int _0^{\infty } dx \sigma E_a \exp (-x/\delta _e)\cos (m_at-x/\delta _e)= L\sigma \delta _e E_a\sin (m_at+\pi /4)/\sqrt{2}\equiv I_a\sin (m_at+\pi /4)$ with the length L of the slab in the y direction, (22) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} I_a&=&\frac{\sigma \delta _e E_aL}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{\sigma \delta _e g_{a\gamma \gamma }a_0BL}{\sqrt{2}} \\ &=& 0.7\times 10^{-9} \, \mbox{A} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg )^{1/2} \, \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg )\bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ) , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where we have adopted high-quality 6N copper with electrical conductivity σ ≃ 3.3 × 107 eV at a low temperature of the order of 1 K. We have used the parameters for the dark matter axion energy density $\rho _a = 0.3 \, \mbox{GeV}\, \mbox{cm}^{-3} = m_a^2a_0^2/2$ and the axion model gγ = 1 (g aγγ = gγ α/πf a ). These values are used throughout the paper.

The power of the Joule heating by the electric current I a is given by (23) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} P_a & =& LR\sigma E_a^2\int _0^{\infty }dx \exp \bigg (-\frac{2x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\, \overline{\cos ^2(m_at-x/\delta _e)}=\frac{LR\delta _e\sigma E_a^2}{4} \\ &\simeq& 0.3\times 10^{-22} \, \mbox{W} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg )^{1/2} \, \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg )^2 \, \bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ) \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{R}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where R denotes the side length of the slab (the surface area is R × L), LRδ e is the volume of the conductor in which the electric current flows, and $\overline{O}$ is the time average of O. In order to detect the electric current, we amplify the power P a using the LC circuit [17,18].

Because the thermal noise of the system at a temperature of T = 1 K is given by (24) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} P_T=\frac{T\delta \omega }{2\pi }\simeq 3.3\times 10^{-20} \, \mbox{W} \, \bigg (\frac{T}{1 \, \rm K}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{\delta \omega }{10^{-6}m_a}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{m_a}{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}\bigg ), \end{eqnarray*} $$ the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) is given by (25) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \frac{S}{N} &=& \frac{P_a}{P_T}Q_{LC}\sqrt{\frac{\delta \omega t_{obs}}{2\pi }} \\ &\simeq& 4.5\times 10^{-2} Q_\mathrm{LC}\sqrt{\frac{t_\mathrm{obs}}{1 \, \rm s}} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg )^2 \, \bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg )\\ &&\times\,\bigg (\frac{R}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{1 \, \rm K}{T}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-6}m_a}{\delta \omega }\bigg )^{1/2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where QLC denotes the Q factor in the LC circuit used to amplify the power P a , and tobs is the observation time. QLC is given such that $Q_\mathrm{LC}=\frac{1}{R_\mathrm{LC}}\sqrt{L_i/C}$ , with inductance L i of the coil, capacitance C of the condenser, and resistance RLC of the circuit. In particular, RLC = R/(σ Lδ e ). Thus, we find (26) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{LC}=\sqrt{\frac{2\sigma }{m_a}}\times \sqrt{\frac{L_i}{C}}\bigg (\frac{L}{R}\bigg )\simeq 2.5\times 10^6\sqrt{\frac{10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}}{m_a}} \sqrt{\frac{L_i}{C}}\bigg (\frac{L}{R}\bigg ) . \end{eqnarray*} $$ Therefore, we obtain a sufficiently large signal-to-noise ratio to detect the electric current induced by the dark matter axion, even if the observational time t obs is 1 s.

We would like to point out that the Q value associated with the absorption by the flat conductors is derived using the definition Q = m a U/2P a , with the energy U of the radiation in the space between the two slabs, (27) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} U\equiv \frac{1}{2}\int \big (\overline{E_z^2(\mbox{outside})}+\overline{B_y^2(\mbox{outside})}\big ) dV=\frac{LRE_a^2l}{2(m_a\delta _e)^2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$ with l = π/m a . We find that (28) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} Q=\frac{m_al}{\delta _e\sigma (m_a\delta _e)^2}=\frac{\pi }{4}\sqrt{\frac{2\sigma }{m_a}}\simeq 2\times 10^6 \sqrt{\frac{10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}}{m_a}} . \end{eqnarray*} $$ This formula is almost identical to the QLC factor in the LC circuit.

In order to obtain a high value of the electric current I a , we need to exactly tune the spacing l = π/m a between the two slabs. But, such an exact tuning is not possible because $\delta _e=\sqrt{2/m_a\sigma }\simeq 1.6\times 10^{-6} \, \mbox{cm} \, \sqrt{10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a}$ . In an actual experiment we tune it approximately. Thus, we need to see the electric current and its power in the approximate tuning.

We note that, in general, the electric current I a (l) flowing in the slab is given by (29) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} I_a(l) & =& L\sigma E_1\int _0^{\infty }dx\exp \bigg ({-}\frac{x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\big (\cos (m_at-x/\delta _e)+A\sin (m_a t-x/\delta _e)\big ) \\ &=& \frac{L\sigma \delta _e E_1}{\sqrt{2}}\bigg (\sin \bigg (m_at+\frac{\pi }{4}\bigg )+A\sin \bigg (m_at-\frac{\pi }{4}\bigg )\bigg ), \end{eqnarray*} $$ and the power of the Joule heating P a (l) is (30) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} P_a(l) &=& LR\sigma E_1^2\int _0^{\infty }dx \exp \bigg ({-}\frac{2x}{\delta _e}\bigg )\overline{\big (\cos (m_at-x/\delta _e)+A\sin (m_a t-x/\delta _e)\big )^2} \\ &=& \frac{LR\delta _e\sigma (E_1^2+(E_1A)^2)}{4}, \end{eqnarray*} $$ where the parameters E1 and A depend on the spacing l between the two slabs.

When we take the spacing l = π/m a + δl with δl ≪ π/m a (then, tan δ ≃ −2/( m a δl)), the parameters E1 and E1A are found such that (31) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} E_1=-\frac{E_a(y+1)}{2y^2+2y+1}, \quad E_1A=\frac{E_a y}{2y^2+2y+1} \qquad \mbox{with } y\equiv \delta l/2\delta _e. \end{eqnarray*} $$ The tuning y ≪ 1 would be very difficult because $\delta _e\simeq 1.6\times 10^{-6} \, \mbox{cm} \, \sqrt{10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a}$ . But even if we tune y such that y ∼ 102, i.e. δl ∼ 10−4 cm, we obtain the electric current, I a (l = π/m a + δl) = −I a (δl)cos ( m a t), (32) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} I_a(\delta l) &=& \frac{\sigma \delta _e E_aL}{2y} \\ &\simeq& 1.4\times 10^{-11} \, \mbox{A} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-4} \, \rm cm}{\delta l}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg ) \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ), \end{eqnarray*} $$ and the corresponding power, P a (δl) ≡ P a (l = π/m a + δl), (33) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} P_a(\delta l) &=& \frac{LR\delta _e \sigma E_a^2}{8y^2} \\ &\simeq& 1.5\times 10^{-26} \, \mbox{W} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-4} \, \rm cm}{\delta l}\bigg )^2 \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg )^{3/2} \, \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg )^2\\ &&\times\,\bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{R}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) . \end{eqnarray*} $$ Then, we find the signal-to-noise ratio, S(δl)/ N, (34) $$ \begin{eqnarray*} \frac{S(\delta l)}{N} &=& \frac{P_a(\delta l)}{P_T}Q_\mathrm{LC}\sqrt{\frac{\delta \omega t_\mathrm{obs}}{2\pi }} \\ &\simeq& 2.3\times 10^{-5}Q_\mathrm{LC}\sqrt{\frac{t_\mathrm{obs}}{1 \, \rm s}} \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-4} \, \rm cm}{\delta l}\bigg )^2 \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-5} \, \rm eV}{m_a}\bigg )^2 \, \bigg (\frac{B}{5 \, \rm T}\bigg )^2 \\ &&\times\, \bigg (\frac{\sigma }{3.3\times 10^7 \, \rm eV}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{L}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{R}{10 \, \rm cm}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{1 \, \rm K}{T}\bigg ) \, \bigg (\frac{10^{-6}m_a}{\delta \omega }\bigg )^{1/2} , \end{eqnarray*} $$ where $Q_\mathrm{LC}=\frac{1}{R_\mathrm{LC}}\sqrt{L_i/C}\sim 10^6\sqrt{L_i/C}\sqrt{10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}/m_a}$ , using L = 10 cm and R = 10 cm.

In an actual experiment using QLC = 106, we can search the spacing Δl ∼ 6 cm within one day if we tune the spacing with the speed $\partial _t\delta l \sim 10^{-4} \, \rm cm/s$ ( tobs = 1 s for S/N > 1). This covers the range of the QCD axion mass $m_a\sim 10^{-5} \, \mbox{eV}$
because π/m a ∼ 6 cm. On the other hand, in order to cover the range of the axion mass ∼10−4 eV (π/m a ∼ 6 × 10−1 cm), we can search it for 10 days if we tune the spacing with the speed $\partial _t\delta l \sim 10^{-4} \, \rm cm/(10^2 \, s)$ ( tobs = 102 s for S/ N > 1). But, to cover the range of m a = 10−3 eV, we need tobs = 106 s for S /N > 1, so it takes more than 10 years to search the spacing Δl ∼ 0.06 cm. However, if we can tune the spacing δl = 10−5 cm, by taking $\partial _t\delta l \sim 10^{-5} \, \rm cm/(10^2 \, s)$ ( tobs = 102 s for S/ N > 1), we can search the spacing Δl ∼ 0.06 cm within 10 days even for m a = 10−3 eV.

On the other hand, when we search the mass ∼3 × 10−6 eV (π/m a ∼ 20 cm), we need larger slabs, such as L = R = 40 cm for our approximation of an infinitely extending conductor to hold. Then, the power of the Joule heating or the S/N ratio is much bigger so that detection is much easier because we can take δl = 10 −3 cm and tobs = 1 s, as we can see from Eq. (34). In this way, it turns out that the new method of axion detection is very effective for the QCD axion search.
